title: 104_hr2166
content: The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" introduces a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations under Subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new part, titled "Minimum Tax on Certain Foreign and Foreign-Owned Corporations," establishes a minimum tax requirement for these entities. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on specific foreign and foreign-owned corporations based on their taxable income from different business activities. This applies to corporations that are either 25-percent foreign-owned domestic corporations or foreign corporations with gross income. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations with substantial foreign-related person transactions during the taxable year. An exception applies if a qualified section 482 agreement is in effect when the corporation files its tax return. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations with substantial foreign-related person transactions during the taxable year. An exception applies if a qualified section 482 agreement is in effect with the corporation for all transactions with related parties in any category of business activities. The Secretary may enter into a qualified section 482 agreement if it will accurately reflect the corporation's taxable income. The agreement can also have retroactive effects on prior taxable years if deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary may enter into a qualified section 482 agreement to reflect the corporation's taxable income accurately, with retroactive effects on prior taxable years if necessary. For corporations with unclassifiable activities, a minimum tax of 35 percent is imposed on gross receipts from property sales or leases. The section provides waivers in cases of casualty or disaster, excludes foreign taxes from taxable income, and establishes an applicable profit percentage for each calendar year after 1995. The Secretary prescribes an applicable profit percentage for each category of business activities based on average earnings rates of domestic corporations. The earnings rate of a domestic corporation is determined by the ratio of adjusted book income to gross receipts from business activities, excluding certain taxes. The tax code defines terms related to foreign ownership and transactions, with specific thresholds for substantial foreign-related person transactions by corporations. The tax code sets thresholds for corporate transactions with foreign entities, limiting deductions to $2,000,000 or 10% of gross income. Business activities are categorized by 3-digit codes, allowing for aggregation when appropriate. The tax code sets thresholds for corporate transactions with foreign entities, limiting deductions to $2,000,000 or 10% of gross income. Business activities are categorized by 3-digit codes, allowing for aggregation when appropriate, including classifications for a classification system other than the Standard Industrial Classification Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
